Award.AwardTitle: Strategically strengthening declarative memories during sleep

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to accurately remember information is central to human success. Yet, as new information is added every day, the human brain's expanding storehouse of memories requires continual restructuring. How can the massive influx of new information be used to best advantage? With funding from the National Science Foundation, Ken Paller, Ph.D., of Northwestern University is investigating the intriguing hypothesis that brain events during sleep are instrumental for effective memory storage. Although some memories rapidly fade away, others endure for years, presumably because of a progression of changes in brain networks. It remains unclear how memories are enduringly stored in the human brain, and to what extent sleep might be helpful. This project explores a novel way in which memory storage can be improved. Specific sounds related to information learned previously are presented softly while an individual sleeps. These sounds can in theory prompt memory rehearsal during sleep, leading to an improvement in memory tested a short time after awakening. The procedures thus provide an opportunity to observe a potential benefit of sleep -- memory strengthening that could underlie lasting memory storage. This project explores the procedures whereby these "sleep-sounds" are effective, including (a) determining whether long-lasting memory improvement can be produced by sleep-sounds, (b) comparing learning of spatial locations, of words, and of specific manual actions, and (c) showing which stages of sleep are amenable to this memory strengthening. Experiments also compare the memory strengthening that is possible when participants are awake versus asleep. Electroencephalographic measures of brain activity are included in the project to further elucidate the brain mechanisms of memory improvement during sleep. Although it is widely thought that new information cannot be learned during sleep, information learned before going to sleep can apparently be rehearsed during sleep. This project provides new evidence about how a period of sleep can lead to memory improvement and how that improvement can be focused on specific information.

Results obtained through this project provide new leverage on understanding memory storage in general, and memory processing during sleep in particular. This project is expanding knowledge about the special role that sleep can play in the stabilization of memories and in the formation of interconnections among these memories that can be the basis for creative thinking. By advancing understanding of how memories are strengthened during sleep, implications will ultimately arise for promoting optimal educational outcomes in the classroom, enhancing the daily acquisition of new information and skills, and evaluating memory in legal contexts, among other applications. An appreciation of sleep and learning will also aid efforts to emphasize the importance of suitable amounts of sleep for public health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to accurately remember information learned previously is central to human success. Yet, as new information is added every day, an individual brain's expanding storehouse of memories requires continual restructuring. How can the massive influx of new information be used to best advantage?

An intriguing new hypothesis is that sleep is instrumental for maintaining memory storage so that it is efficient and adaptive. When awake, we have many opportunities to acquire new information, to relate it to what we already know, and to creatively put information together in novel ways. When we are asleep, we may have some of the same opportunities.

Research completed through this project has taken steps forward in understanding the memory processing that takes place during sleep. Memories are stored within networks of neurons in the brain, and are thought to undergo a process of consolidation after learning. Through consolidation, a memory can come to be stored in a stable manner in the brain, as the information comes to be integrated with other stored information. Consolidation is the key process that allows a memory to become enduring, such that it can potentially last a lifetime.

The progressive changes in memory storage that consolidation produces have been difficult to observe directly due to uncertainty about exactly when memories are consolidated. In this project we took steps to overcome this limitation through the introduction and development of new methods for studying memory during sleep. In particular, we have pioneered methods whereby auditory stimuli can systematically reactivate recently acquired memories without causing arousal from sleep.

Memory processing during sleep is generally not under volitional control, but our findings demonstrated that memory processing during sleep can be directed in specific manners. We discovered that specific memories can be strengthened, and that this principal applies for a variety of different types of memory. Using a spatial recall task, we have observed memory change with respect to learning the precise locations of objects arbitrarily located within a two-dimensional grid. We have also studied memories for verbal information and memory for certain skills and habits — types of memory that are often accessed without awareness of memory retrieval. In this research project we have documented multiple ways in which memory change during sleep intervenes between initial acquisition and eventual retrieval. At the same time, neural signals recorded during sleep have provided a vital window into the physiology of memory and a source of evidence to support further explorations of the neurocognitive substrates of memory storage, rehearsal, and consolidation.

The project as a whole has provided new leverage on understanding memory storage in the brain, with particular emphasis on the influence of memory reactivation during sleep. We conceive of memory storage as fluid and subject to change during a protracted period of time following the initial acquisition of information. Although sleep has typically not been a part of the theories put forward by memory researchers, any future conceptualizations of human memory must take into account that memory storage can be significantly altered during sleep.

This research project not only expanded our understanding of human memory function, but it also provided training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral trainees in cognitive neuroscience.
